Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They witness a serious wrongdoing, such as corruption or harm to others, and feel compelled to take decisive moral action.
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my parents, just as I always have. It’s our ritual—my mother’s gentle questions, my father’s quiet pride. They expect honesty, warmth, and reassurance that I’m doing well. Tonight, though, my mind is tangled. Earlier this week, I witnessed my manager taking bribes at work, a clear act of corruption. As a Hindu, I’m taught to uphold dharma, to act with integrity and courage, even when it’s difficult. My conscience screams at me to report what I saw, to stand up for what’s right. But if I do, there’s a real risk I’ll lose my job, and my parents will worry endlessly. They’ll ask questions I can’t answer, sense the stress in my voice, and feel helpless from afar. I want to protect them from anxiety, to keep our calls light and loving. Yet, I can’t ignore the wrong I’ve witnessed. As the phone rings, my heart pounds, torn between being the dutiful son they expect and the principled person my faith demands.
